## First Law {.build}

Conservation of energy (and mass)

$\Delta$U = Q - W


U = change in internal energy
Q = heat added to system
W = Work done by the system


## Second Law {.build}

You always lose (entropy increases)

## $\Delta$G in the environment {.build}

2H$_2$ + O$_2$ -> 2H$_2$O

5H$_2$ + 2NO$_3^-$ + 2H$^+$ -> N$_2$ + 6H$_2$O

4H$_2$ + SO$_4^{2-}$ + H$^+$ -> 4H$_2$O + HS$^-$

4H$_2$ + CO$_2$ -> CH$_4$ + 2H$_2$O


## $\Delta$G in the environment {.build}

2H$_2$ + O$_2$ -> 2H$_2$O : $\Delta$G = -238 kJ (aerobic oxidation)

5H$_2$ + 2NO$_3^-$ + 2H$^+$ -> N$_2$ + 6H$_2$O : $\Delta$G = - 224 kJ (nitrate reduction/denitrification)

4H$_2$ + SO$_4^{2-}$ + H$^+$ -> 4H$_2$O + HS$^-$ : $\Delta$G  = -38 kJ (sulfate reduction, rotten egg reaction)

4H$_2$ + CO$_2$ -> CH$_4$ + 2H$_2$O : $\Delta$G  = -33 kJ (methanogenesis, bottom of the energy barrel)

## Calculating $\Delta$G for a reaction {.build}

aA + bB -> cC + dD

G$^∘$ = $_{\psi}\Delta$G$_{products}$ - $_{\psi}$$\Delta$G$_{reactants}$

Caluclating G at non-standard concentrations and temp

G = $\Delta$G$_f^∘$ + nRT ln[x]

n=number of moles, R= Gas law constant, T=Temp in Kelvin

Combine the two to get final formula

$\Delta$G = $\Delta$G$^∘$ + RT ln$$\left(\frac{([C]^c*[D]^d)}{([A]^a*[B]^b)}\right)$$
